H0.text: Be covered with moss and rocks is the most likely outcome after twenty years when a farmer in Massachusetts stops using a 10‑acre field, fences it off, stops cutting the grass, and stops allowing livestock to graze.

H1.text: A mature hardwood forest is what the 10‑acre field would most likely become after twenty years of being fenced off, left uncut, and ungrazed by livestock on the farmer’s Massachusetts farm.

H2.text: The area will be grown over with bushes and small trees after twenty years when the farmer stops using a 10‑acre field, fences it off, stops cutting the grass, and stops allowing livestock to graze on it.

H3.text: Be barren due to lack of maintenance after twenty years on the 10‑acre field that the farmer stopped using, fenced off, and where he ceased cutting grass and allowing livestock to graze, in an effort to preserve wildlife on his Massachusetts farm.

A6.text: Many grassland ecosystems are maintained by disturbance, such as fire and grazing by large animals, or else the process of succession will change them to forest or shrubland.

A7.text: In North American semi-arid grasslands, the introduction of livestock ranching and absence of fire was observed to cause a transition away from grasses to woody vegetation, particularly mesquite.
